qas.question: What states that there is no general federal common law?

answers.text: the doctrine of Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins

qas.question: When was the doctrine of Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins put into effect?
Why can't federal courts just make up law?

answers.text: lack the plenary power possessed by state courts

qas.question: When are states allowed to use plenary power?

answers.text: absence of constitutional or statutory provisions replacing the common law

qas.question: Who won Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins?
When was the Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins rescinded?
What type of power do Federal courts have that state courts do not?
What is an example of a law that is not an extension of English common law?
Maritime law is not subject to what limitation?

context: Under <a0_0>the doctrine of <b4_0>Erie Railroad Co.<b4_0/> v. Tompkins<a0_0/> (<a1_0><b5_0>1938<b5_0/><a1_0/>), there is no general federal common law. Although federal courts can create federal common law in the form of case law, such law must be linked one way or another to the interpretation of a particular federal constitutional provision, statute, or regulation (which in turn was enacted as part of the Constitution or after). Federal courts <a2_0>lack the <b6_0>plenary<b6_0/> power possessed by state courts<a2_0/> to simply make up law, which the latter are able to do in the <a3_0>absence of constitutional or statutory provisions replacing the common law<a3_0/>. Only in a few narrow limited areas, like <b7_0>maritime<b7_0/> law, has the Constitution expressly authorized the continuation of English common law at the federal level (meaning that in those areas federal courts can continue to make law as they see fit, subject to the limitations of <b8_0>stare decisis<b8_0/>).
